Genekitr: Gene Analysis Toolkit based on R Yunze Liu 2022-05-27 üìñ Introduction Welcome to use genekitr! The book is a tutorial for gene information query, ID conversion, enrichment analysis, and publication-level plotting. If you are new to R, do not worry, I will set enough example codes to guide you through the book. After reading this book, you could plot your figures based on your analysis result. üìö Content Part 1 (Search information) introduces how to search gene metadata and PubMed papers. Part 2 (ID conversion) describes ID conversion among symbol & alias, NCBI Entrez, Ensembl, and Uniprot. Part 3 (Enrichment analysis) describes accessible functions to enrichment results, including GO, KEGG, and GSEA. Part 4 (Plotting) includes 14 GO plots, 7 KEGG plots, 5 GSEA plots, 2 Venn plots, and 1 Volcano plot. ‚ù§Ô∏è Welcome to contribute Book source code at https://github.com/GangLiLab/book_genekitr. If you get some ideas or issues, please feel free to post feedback.
1 Search gene metadata 1.1 Supported organisms 1.2 Basic search

1 Search gene metadata If users have groups of genes to check their names, location, GC content etc., they can use genInfo() function to quickly check. 1.1 Supported organisms Support 196 vertebrate species, 120 plant species and 2 bacteria species # install.packages('DT') library(genekitr) DT::datatable(ensOrg_name, options = list(pageLength = 20)) A user could select an organism name from the latin_short_name column. The common name is acceptable for popular research species (e.g., human, mouse, rat, fly, zebrafish, worm, chicken). Take human as an example; its official Latin short name is ‚Äúhappens,‚Äù but hg," ‚Äúhsa,‚Äù ‚Äúhs,‚Äù or ‚Äúhuman‚Äù are also acceptable. 1.2 Basic search There are only three arguments in genInfo(): id: gene id (symbol, Entrez or Ensembl) or protein id org: organism name unique: TRUE or FALSE. Commonly, one gene could have many other types of matched records. For example, the human HBD gene has three matched Entrez IDs: 3045, 85349, and 100187828. If TRUE, only return a one-to-one match result with minimal NAs. id <- "HBD" uniq_res <- genInfo(id, org = 'hs', unique = TRUE) all_res <- genInfo(id, org = 'hs', unique = FALSE) head(uniq_res) ## input_id symbol entrezid ensembl uniprot chr start end width strand ## 2 HBD HBD 3045 ENSG00000223609 A0N071; P02042 11 5232678 5243657 10980 -1 ## gene_name ncbi_alias ensembl_alias gc_content gene_biotype transcript_count ## 2 hemoglobin subunit delta <NA> <NA> 38.32 protein_coding 5 ## hgnc_id omim ccds reactome ## 2 HGNC:4829 142000 CCDS31376 R-HSA-109582; R-HSA-983231 ## ucsc mirbase_id ## 2 uc057yha.1; uc285iqp.1; uc285iqq.1; uc057yhb.1; uc057yhc.1 <NA> head(all_res) ## input_id symbol entrezid ensembl ## 1 HBD HBD 100187828 <NA> ## 2 HBD HBD 3045 ENSG00000223609 ## 3 HBD KRT87P 85349 ENSG00000135477 ## uniprot chr start end width ## 1 P02042; A0N071; D1MGP8; C9JRG0; E9PEW8; Q4F786; E9PFT6; B2M1S8; D1MGQ0 <NA> <NA> <NA> <NA> ## 2 A0N071; P02042 11 5232678 5243657 10980 ## 3 A6NCN2 12 52250466 52258867 8402 ## strand gene_name ncbi_alias ensembl_alias ## 1 <NA> hypophosphatemic bone disease <NA> <NA> ## 2 -1 hemoglobin subunit delta <NA> <NA> ## 3 -1 keratin 87, pseudogene HBD; KRT121P; KRTHBP4; psihHbD KRT121P; KRTHBP4; psihHbD ## gc_content gene_biotype transcript_count hgnc_id omim ccds ## 1 <NA> <NA> <NA> <NA> <NA> <NA> ## 2 38.32 protein_coding 5 HGNC:4829 142000 CCDS31376 ## 3 53.36 transcribed_unprocessed_pseudogene 2 HGNC:30198 NA <NA> ## reactome ucsc mirbase_id ## 1 <NA> <NA> <NA> ## 2 R-HSA-109582; R-HSA-983231 uc057yha.1; uc285iqp.1; uc285iqq.1; uc057yhb.1; uc057yhc.1 <NA> ## 3 <NA> uc286ipk.1; uc286ipl.1 <NA> colnames(all_res) ## [1] "input_id" "symbol" "entrezid" "ensembl" "uniprot" ## [6] "chr" "start" "end" "width" "strand" ## [11] "gene_name" "ncbi_alias" "ensembl_alias" "gc_content" "gene_biotype" ## [16] "transcript_count" "hgnc_id" "omim" "ccds" "reactome" ## [21] "ucsc" "mirbase_id"
